title: MADA Portfolio
text: This site documents my work for Modern Applied Data Analysis (MADA), including weekly reflections, tool setup, and my semester-long data analysis project. It will evolve as the course progresses.

title: About Me
text:
Hi everyone, my name is Alexandra (Alex) Tejada-Strop, and I’m a DrPH student in Health Policy and Management. I have a background in public health and laboratory science and have used R for basic data cleaning, analysis, and visualization. I’m comfortable with statistics conceptually, but I’m still developing my applied modeling skills. My experience with Git and GitHub is limited, so I’m looking forward to getting more practice with reproducible workflows.
In this course, I hope to strengthen my skills in reproducible data analysis, model evaluation, and using tools like Quarto and tidymodels. I’m interested in applying what we learn to real-world public health or surveillance data, potentially aligned with my dissertation or professional work.
I work full-time at the CDC for the Division of Hepatitis at the Laboratory Branch. I also have a 10 year old son that loves sports, and my husband Jared. Our favorite thing it to travel and try new restaurants. The puppy in the picture is our cavapoo, Maple.
To know more about me, here is the link to my LinkedIn profile.

title: MADA Course Project
text:
Tentative Interests
I am currently interested in exploring questions related to:

Public health data

Health outcomes and disparities
Reproducible data analysis workflows

title: MADA Course Project
text:
Next Steps

Identify a suitable dataset
Refine a research question
Set up a project repository using the course template

title: Weekly Reflections
text: This week focused on understanding the full data analysis workflow, from question and data matching to reporting results. A key takeaway for me was the importance of reproducibility and interpretation over applying advanced models.
